metadata.case_name: State of Bombay & Ors. v. Hospital Mazdoor Sabha & Ors.

facts.text: Respondents 2 and 3 (Mrs. Vatsala Narayan and Mrs. Ruth Isaac) were employed as Ward servants in the J.J. group of Hospitals.
Superintendent of J.J. group of Hospitals informed respondents 2 and 3 by notices that their services would be terminated with effect from dates mentioned, and services were terminated accordingly.
In place of respondents 2 and 3, two State servants discharged from Civil Supplies Department were appointed.
Writ petition filed by respondents alleging retrenchment void as it did not comply with ss. 25F and 25H of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947; claimed mandamus for reinstatement.
Tendolkar J. dismissed writ petition holding non-compliance with s.25F did not invalidate orders; remedy under s.33(1); s.25H not applicable.
Bombay High Court Appellate Bench reversed Tendolkar J., held orders invalid for contravention of s.25F; hospitals constitute industry; allowed writ and issued mandamus.

J.J. group consists of five Hospitals; started from 1835 for medical education and relief; funded by donations and government grants (Rs.27 lakhs from budget head 38-Medical); under administrative control of Surgeon-General; day-to-day by Superintendent (full-time employee); residential staff full-time employees paid by appellant.
Group serves as clinical training ground for students of Grant Medical College (Government college) for degrees from Bombay University.
Services of respondents 2 and 3 retrenched to make room for other Government servants with longer service retrenched from Civil Supplies Department.
No compensation as per s.25F(b) paid to respondents 2 and 3 at time of retrenchment.
Respondents 2 and 3 in continuous service for not less than one year.

legal_issues.text: Whether contravention of material provisions of s.25F of the Act rendered the impugned orders invalid.
Whether relevant provisions of the Act apply to the group of Hospitals run by the appellant; are they an industry within the meaning of s.2(j) of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Orders terminating services of respondents 2 and 3 were not void; non-compliance with s.25F does not invalidate orders; remedy under s.33(1) or s.25J.
J.J. group of Hospitals does not constitute an industry; provisions of Act inapplicable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(j), Industrial Disputes Act, 1947; noscitur a sociis rule

respondent_arguments.text: Retrenchment of respondents 2 and 3 void as it did not comply with mandatory provisions of ss.25F and 25H.
J.J. group of Hospitals constitutes an industry under s.2(j).

court_reasoning.text: s.25F(b) imposes condition precedent: no workman shall be retrenched until paid compensation; mandatory; non-compliance renders retrenchment invalid and inoperative; s.25J covers other recoveries, not s.25F(b).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Failure to comply with s.25F renders impugned orders invalid.

court_reasoning.text: s.2(j) definition wide: 'industry' means any business, trade, undertaking etc. and includes calling, service etc.; inclusive definition extends scope; noscitur a sociis inapplicable where wider words deliberately used.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words of wide import to be read widely; hospitals not excluded.

court_reasoning.text: Profit motive or capital investment not essential; sovereign/regal functions excluded, but welfare activities like hospitals not; character of activity decides: systematic rendering of material services to community with employer-employee cooperation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Running hospitals is undertaking under s.2(j) whether by private or government.

court_reasoning.text: Quid pro quo not necessary; subsequent addition of 'services in hospitals' to First Schedule corroborates.

holdings.text: Contravention of s.25F renders retrenchment orders invalid and inoperative.
J.J. group of Hospitals run by State is an 'undertaking' and thus an 'industry' under s.2(j); Act applies.

precedents_cited.case_name: D. N. Banerji v. P. R. Mukherjee Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Municipal activities analogous to trade/business are industry even without profit/capital; disputes with employees covered.

precedents_cited.case_name: Baroda Borough Municipality v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Municipal undertakings analogous to trade/business are industry.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sri Vishuddhananda Saraswathi Marwari Hospital v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Labour Appellate Tribunal held hospital is undertaking under s.2(j).

precedents_cited.case_name: The Federated State School Teachers Association of Australia And The State of Victoria Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Isaacs J. dissent: industrial disputes involve capital-labour cooperation for human needs; true character of activity decides.

precedents_cited.case_name: Corporation of Glasgow v. Glasgow Tramway and Omnibus Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Wide words not cut down by ejusdem generis.
Regal/sovereign functions are primary inalienable functions of government.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Retrenchment conditions mandatory; definition of industry wide and inclusive; applies to hospitals as undertaking.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by State of Bombay, upheld Bombay High Court; retrenchment orders invalid for non-compliance with s.25F; J.J. Hospitals an industry under s.2(j); writ of mandamus issued for reinstatement.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ petition allowed; mandamus directing reinstatement of respondents 2 and 3.

key_quotes.text: 'no workman employed in any industry who has been in continuous service for not less than one year under an employer shall be retrenched by that employer until...'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.25F(b) to emphasize mandatory condition precedent.

key_quotes.text: 'industry means any business, trade, undertaking, manufacture or calling of employers and includes any calling, service, employment, handicraft, or industrial occupation or avocation of workmen.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core definition of s.2(j); wide and inclusive.

key_quotes.text: 'an activity systematically or habitually undertaken for the production or distribution of goods or for the rendering of material services to the community... with the help of employees is an undertaking.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Working test for 'undertaking' applied to hospitals.
